description: Possibly from Malay kampong, kampung (“group of buildings, village”), via Dutch or Portuguese, altered under the influence of Etymology 2. Doublet of kampung.

entries.meaning: An enclosure within which workers, prisoners, or soldiers are confined.
examples: Synonyms: gaol, jail, pen, pound, prison; see also Thesaurus:prison

entries.meaning: An enclosure for secure storage.
A group of buildings situated close together, e.g. for a school or block of offices.

description: From Middle English compounen, from Middle French componre, compondre (“to put together”), from Latin componō, from Latin com- (“together”) + ponō (“to put”).

entries.meaning: Composed of elements; not simple.
(mathematics) Dealing with numbers of various denominations of quantity, or with processes more complex than the simple process.
(music) An octave higher than originally (i.e. a compound major second is equivalent to a major ninth).
Anything made by combining several things.
examples: Synonyms: amalgam, blend, combination, composite, mix, mixture

entries.meaning: (chemistry) A substance formed by chemical bonding of two or more elements in definite proportions by weight.
examples: Coordinate terms: substance, element, mixture, composite

entries.meaning: (chemistry, dated) A substance made from any combination of ingredients.
(linguistics) A lexeme that consists of more than one stem.
(linguistics) A lexeme that consists of more than one stem or an affix, e.g. bookshop, high school or non-standard.
examples: In the majority of the compounds of non- the hyphen is usually retained; but it is commonly omitted in the case of a few, such as nonconformist, nonentity, nonsense, in which the etymology has been to some extent lost sight of.

entries.meaning: (rail transport) A compound locomotive, a steam locomotive with both high-pressure and low-pressure cylinders.
Short for compound exercise.

verbs.description: compound (third-person singular simple present compounds, present participle compounding, simple past and past participle compounded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form (a resulting mixture) by combining different elements, ingredients, or parts; to mingle with something else.
(transitive, law) To settle by agreeing on less than the claim, or on different terms than those stipulated.
(transitive) To settle amicably; to adjust by agreement.
(intransitive) To come to terms of agreement; to settle by a compromise.
examples: to compound with someone / for something

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To compose; to constitute.
(intransitive, finance) To increase in value with interest, where the interest is earned on both the principal sum and prior earned interest.
(transitive, see usage notes) To worsen a situation.
(horse racing, intransitive) Of a horse: to fail to maintain speed.
examples: At the hill, the Warrior must have been at least ten lengths in front of Wild Dayrell; but he compounded about 200 yards on the T. Y. C. side of the Red House.
